channel.title: Maria.engineer -- RSS Feed
channel.description: Personal Website for Maria Mateescu - Software Engineer turned Personal and Professional Coach.

item.title: Gaslighter's Guide to Escaping Responsibility
item.description: A darkly satirical field guide to emotional manipulation, plausible deniability, and covert abuse.

item.title: Nihilistic Eat, Pray, Love
item.description: A nihilist's Eat Pray Love: routines, language study, gym crushes, and the messy act of choosing yourself, again and again, even when nothing matters anyway.

item.title: The worst advice I got as a software engineer
item.description: Why 'code wins arguments' became the worst career advice I ever received as a software engineer. How focusing only on technical solutions while ignoring workplace dynamics led to my biggest professional mistake - and what I learned about the human side of engineering.

item.title: Korea: After the Honeymoon
item.description: A 6-month retrospective on moving to Seoul, exploring how relationship psychology applies to loving a city after the honeymoon period ends. On choosing problems you can live with, finding equilibrium, and committing to make it work long-term.

item.title: Learning to be Enough
item.description: I was the gifted child who was never enough. This is the story of my journey of learning how to be enough.

item.title: When Crush Turns to Like
item.description: What's the difference between a crush and actually liking someone? When we actually like someone we may need to change what we to do about it. But while the solution is simple, it's not easy.

item.title: An Alternative to Journaling: Writing Fiction
item.description: I have always struggled with journaling, yet every therapist has recommended it. I realised fiction writing was my form of journaling - a freedom to express myself that I could not through traditional journaling. Just because it's fictional, doesn't make it any less true.

item.title: Building Emotional Intelligence and Healing Through Fiction
item.description: Discover how fiction builds emotional intelligence better than self-help books. Learn why K-dramas, novels, and stories teach empathy and emotional healing through the 'show don't tell' approach that transforms how we understand ourselves and others.

item.title: Happiness isn't the goal, it's the metric
item.description: Chasing happiness makes it impossible to find it. After trying to find meaning and failing, I learned that happiness works better as a metric than a goal. Only then we can allow the meaningless things to make us happy.

item.title: Am I Overreacting?
item.description: Stop asking 'Am I overreacting?' Learn why your emotional responses are valid, how to trust your intuition, and break free from self-doubt. Includes solo travel safety tips and coaching resources.

item.title: What would you forget?
item.description: Explore the fascinating concept of selective memory erasure and its implications. Drawing from neuroscience, trauma research, and personal reflection, this article examines how memory works, why some memories cause suffering, and offers a transformative alternative to forgetting painful experiences.

item.title: Coaching Tool: Waiting Room
item.description: Discover the 'Waiting Room' coaching tool for managing tasks outside your control and reducing anxiety. Learn how to visualize a mental waiting room for pending tasks, when to use it, and why this simple technique helps maintain focus on what truly matters right now.

item.title: Don't Get Me Wrong
item.description: Being misunderstood is one of my greatest fears. In this post, I explore three types of misunderstanding: from the curious kind when people genuinely want to learn, to the willful kind when people choose not to understand. I share my personal journey of making peace with inevitable misinterpretations, and how coaching others taught me that sometimes, misunderstandings reveal more about what truly matters to the listener.

item.title: I don’t want to be perceived
item.description: Today of all days, the last thing I want to do is be perceived, yet I am writing this blog post, as a challenge to myself as to what it means to be perceived, and that it's not as unsafe as it feels.

item.title: The Importance of Being Seen
item.description: Being seen is one of the most powerful human needs and one of the most overlooked. In the age of smartphones even more so. I look back at the times when people saw me and just how much they affected me.

item.title: We All Need a Little External Validation
item.description: External validation isn’t just okay—it’s essential for human connection and societal functioning. Instead we should learn when it’s healthy, when it’s harmful, and how to find our balance.

item.title: I Learned Not to Trust Perfection
item.description: A personal reflection on the dangers of perfectionism. How it appears in and distorts love, faith, and self-worth. This post explores the myth of perfection through the lens of religion, relationships, and identity, and looks at how I am learning to let go of it.

item.title: AI: A Prediction
item.description: An exploration of AI's current trajectory, the over-reliance on LLMs, the risks of AI-generated code, and why human engineers will remain indispensable. And why I am preparing my popcorn for the next Hindenburg moment.

item.title: Do Not Come Here For Justice
item.description: They say staying is a choice. But staying in a toxic relationship isn't the real choice we make. It’s the pursuit of justice. We believe fairness can be achieved if we just try hard enough, but that belief often keeps us trapped. When justice fails as a survival strategy, what’s left? Letting go can be the hardest but most necessary lesson.

item.title: Just because I can doesn't mean I should
item.description: This Valentine's Day, I reflect on the biggest lesson my past relationship taught me: just because I can, doesn’t mean I should. Independence is great, and it's necessary to create a healthy interdependent relationship. But that doesn't mean doing it all.

item.title: Onboarding: what makes or breaks a team
item.description: Effective onboarding shapes a team’s success. Here’s how to do it right (and what happens when you don’t).

item.title: Why Korea - observations on culture
item.description: Why move to Korea? From cultural values to personal growth, I reflect on how Korea rekindled my ambition and why this country feels like home.

item.title: The Most Under-utilised Gym Motivation Tool: the Gym Crush
item.description: Gym Crushes are well too common, and they make our day better just to see them in the same space as us. Enjoy them as you get ripped for chances are they won't last, unlike the habits they help form.

item.title: Starter Villain: A People Pleaser's Guide to Villainy
item.description: This one is for the people pleasers: let us be villains! An exploration of the start of my villain era, 2024, and the lessons I learned.

item.title: On Urgency: A Reframe
item.description: A rephrase of urgency not just as about deadlines, but as impact. Explore a reframe of the Eisenhower Matrix and learn how cognitive reframing can help you prioritise tasks effectively while avoiding burnout.

item.title: On Decisions and Change
item.description: Decisions are hard, but change doesn't have to be scary. Explore how embracing flexibility, managing uncertainty, and practicing self-compassion can lead to better choices and personal growth.

item.title: Relaxation and Mindfulness: When One Size Does Not Fit All
item.description: Hello from Bali! The ultimate vacation destination, the epitome of relaxation, the mindfulness Mecca... for most people.

item.title: How to Listen with Curiosity
item.description: Lead with curiosity in conversations: How focusing on differences, overcoming assumptions, and embracing the unknown are keys to empathetic communication and effective problem-solving.

item.title: Coaching: Anchors Only Bring Safety in a Storm
item.description: Clinging onto anchors(such as jobs, relationships or commitments that don't serve our deeper desires) can prevent one from moving forward. Security necessary in a turmoil can become a hinderance when freedom calls.

item.title: Stuck on Forwards Compatibility
item.description: A post exploring the parallels between forward compatibility in software engineering and personal growth. Discover how obsessing over planning for the future can hinder real-life progress and how to embrace change more effectively.

item.title: Korean: -ㄹ 거예요 vs -ㄹ께요
item.description: Musings about the Korean language, as a new language learner. The future tenses -ㄹ 거예요 vs -ㄹ께요.

item.title: Things Between Heaven And Earth
item.description: 5★ - Things Between Heaven and Earth, a thought-provoking psychological thriller at the Camden Fringe that brilliantly explores complex human relationships and attachment with authenticity and depth.

item.title: Coaching: You Can't Learn Regular Expressions from Only Positive Examples
item.description: We need to make mistakes in order to learn, just like we need negative examples to train models in Computer Science. Why creating a safe environment for mistakes is crucial for genuine learning and development.

item.title: How to Code with Push Safety in Mind
item.description: Learn how to code with push safety in mind. This comprehensive guide covers backwards and forwards compatibility, common pitfalls in database changes and frontend updates, and best practices for seamless software deployments.

item.title: Software Engineers are Disambiguators
item.description: Explore the evolving role of software engineers as disambiguators, from the history of programming languages to speculations on AI's impact on the field and why I think coding is the least essential part of a software engineer's job.

item.title: Chicken Crisps
item.description: Healthy snack that tastes sinful.

item.title: Withstanding Pressure: Lessons of a Recovering People Pleaser
item.description: As a recovering people pleaser 2024 is the start of my villain era. Here are some mantras and techniques I vow to start and continue using in order to enable myself to withstand pressure and set boundaries.

item.title: Blog Posts: a Meta Post on Writing Posts
item.description: Facing writer’s block? This post tackles common mental biases that can make it hard to identify valuable blog topics and believe others will benefit. Learn how to combat sampling, undercoverage, and egocentric biases.

item.title: When Obvious Isn't Obvious: The Pantomime Trap
item.description: Do childhood pantomimes develop communication skills? Can they encourage perspective-taking and clear communication free of assumptions?

item.title: Ode to Monorepos
item.description: This is my ode to monorepos, and how they simplify refactors, prevent duplicate work, and foster open culture.

item.title: Macro-ifying Microservices: A Way to Think about Microservices
item.description: Microservices have gone from architectural pattern to default for many. But micro doesn't have to mean small. Macro-ifying microservices based on problem spaces simplifies software design.

item.title: A Mirror
item.description: 5★ - Five stars and more, this play is perfection from beginning to end. Poignant in an era where our right of protest is slowly being taken away. While it looks like the censorship in communist regimes, it proves it can be anywhere.

item.title: Beetroot Bors
item.description: Refreshing cold sour soup

item.title: Classic Tiramisu
item.description: A variation on the Italian dessert.

item.title: Salty Birb
item.description: A tequila and pineapple cocktail.

item.title: Cauliflower Cheese
item.description: A simpler cauliflower souffle.

item.title: My Experience Getting Fired
item.description: December 2021, I got fired from my job. It took me a long time to process what happened, maybe I never fully did, but here are some of my learnings.

item.title: Oklahoma!
item.description: 4★ - A modern take on the popular Rodgers and Hammerstein classic, Oklahoma! pulls out all the stops to try and give life to a musical that honestly hasn't aged well.

item.title: Secret Life of Bees
item.description: 5★ - This is a new musical by Duncan Sheik, known for his work on Spring Awakening. Although I had high expectations, I was surprised by how good it turned out to be. The musical is consistently great, and I predict that it will become very popular.

item.title: The Good Person of Szechwan
item.description: 3.5★ - Overall, it was an enjoyable experience. I would describe it as loud and chaotic, yet entertaining and fresh. Considering they took a highly intellectual play by Brecht that some may consider dry, and turned it into something fun and probably enjoyable for the masses, while also not losing the message of the play, is impressive in its own right.

item.title: Operation Mincemeat
item.description: 4★ - This is a really good show - incredibly fun and fresh. Did I mention hilarious? I can't bring myself to go for a full 5 star rating as it was missing something from being great. For example scientific accuracy... A newt does not have an anus.

item.title: George Takei's Allegiance
item.description: 5★ - This musical was nothing short of brilliant. The only thing I could possibly find bad about it is that they did not sell out. I don't really understand how that could happen.

item.title: Lemons Lemons Lemons Lemons
item.description: 2★ - While the premise, in itself, is brilliant, and the topics brought up are interesting and worth presenting in a play, the play under-delivers on all fronts. I cannot call it anything other than a disappointment.

item.title: The Steps of Buying a House in the UK
item.description: Buying a house has been an overwhelming experience. As such I built a list of all the things I had to do and consider, if others may want to use it.

item.title: How to Find a House to Buy a House in the UK
item.description: A record of all the steps I went through to find the house I currently own.

item.title: How to Choose a Survey Type
item.description: This is my guide on how I chose a Survey for a house purchase. One of the more confusing decisions when buying a house was what kind of survey to get. Some surveyors had complicated names, each offering different packages none entirely clear about which you should get and why.

item.title: 5 Ways to Improve your Work Life Balance
item.description: Working longer doesn't mean working better. Many go on about Work Life balance, but many companies have policies that go against it. Here's my top tips on practical things I do to improve my work life balance.

item.title: Grandma's Walnut Cake
item.description: A simple recipe for a nutty loaf cake.

item.title: Grandma's Zacusca
item.description: Traditional Romanian pepper tapenade

item.title: 5 Reasons you Should Build UIs Instead of CLIs
item.description: While the "Real Programmer" will always choose to use CLIs as they are the true sign of competence, good UIs with good defaults are actually the better choice when building tools of the average software engineer.

item.title: Grandma's Krafle
item.description: Doughnuts made from cozonac dough

item.title: Roasting Peppers
item.description: Essential pepper preparation method

item.title: Grandma's Stuffed Peppers
item.description: Peppers with pork and rice stuffing.
